elements.content: We report here a new method to construct metal–organic zeolites (MOZs) via the mixing of dicarboxylic acid and tetrazole ligands. Two anionic MOZs, MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 with BCT and ATN topologies, were developed successfully by this approach and exhibit high selective CO2 uptake and Ln3+ ion exchange.
elements.clean_text: We report here a new method to construct metal-organic zeolites (MOZs) via the mixing of dicarboxylic acid and tetrazole ligands. Two anionic MOZs, MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 with BCT and ATN topologies, were developed successfully by this approach and exhibit high selective CO2 uptake and Ln3+ ion exchange.

elements.content: Presented here is a new method to construct metal−organic zeolites (MOZs) via the mixing of dicarboxylic acid and tetrazole ligands. Two anionic MOZs, MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 with BCT and ATN topologies, were developed successfully by this approach and exhibit high selective gas uptake and Ln3+ ion exchange.
elements.clean_text: Presented here is a new method to construct metal-organic zeolites (MOZs) via the mixing of dicarboxylic acid and tetrazole ligands. Two anionic MOZs, MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 with BCT and ATN topologies, were developed successfully by this approach and exhibit high selective gas uptake and Ln3+ ion exchange.

elements.content: Zeolites are an important class of inorganic crystalline microporous materials. These materials have been used as catalysts, adsorbents, and ion exchangers in many areas. As one kind of stable metal–organic framework, metal–organic zeolites (MOZs) exhibit high surface area and chemical stability. For example, neutral zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) were constructed by tetrahedrally coordinated divalent Zn2+ cations and uninegative imidazolate linkers. Much attention has been paid to synthesizing new frameworks with various topologies and exploring the various properties of MOZs, including gas adsorption/separation, catalysis, sensing, and so on. However, little attention has been paid to developing ionic MOZs for ion exchange.
elements.clean_text: Zeolites are an important class of inorganic crystalline microporous materials. These materials have been used as catalysts, adsorbents, and ion exchangers in many areas. As one kind of stable metal-organic framework, metal-organic zeolites (MOZs) exhibit high surface area and chemical stability. For example, neutral zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) were constructed by tetrahedrally coordinated divalent Zn2+ cations and uninegative imidazolate linkers. Much attention has been paid to synthesizing new frameworks with various topologies and exploring the various properties of MOZs, including gas adsorption/separation, catalysis, sensing, and so on. However, little attention has been paid to developing ionic MOZs for ion exchange.

elements.content: Herein, a new method was developed to construct anionic MOZs by adding an auxiliary 2– charge linker (dicarboxylic acid) into the zinc tetrazolate system. In principle, using dicarboxylic acid ligands to replace parts of the uninegative ligands in this system will generate 4-connected anionic frameworks. On the basis of these considerations, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc) and 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (H2idc) were selected as u2 linkers because of their cheap prices and comparable coordination ability with the tetrazolate ligands. By employment of such a strategy, two porous MOZs with anionic frameworks, [N­(CH3)4]·[Zn2(bdc)­(5-mtz)3]·xsolvent (MOZ-200) and [N­(CH3)4]·[Zn2(idc)­(5-mtz)3]·xsolvent (MOZ-201), where 5-mtz = 5-methyltetrazole, were successfully synthesized. Interestingly, in both compounds, the similar nanotube with an 8-membered ring window consisted of 5-mtz ligands and Zn atoms were observed, and the introduction of dicarboxylic acids with different angles resulted in two different zeolite topologies, BCT and ATN. More importantly, MOZ-200 exhibited permanent porosity and high selective CO2 uptake as well as Ln3+ ion exchange.
elements.clean_text: Herein, a new method was developed to construct anionic MOZs by adding an auxiliary 2- charge linker (dicarboxylic acid) into the zinc tetrazolate system. In principle, using dicarboxylic acid ligands to replace parts of the uninegative ligands in this system will generate 4-connected anionic frameworks. On the basis of these considerations, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc) and 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (H2idc) were selected as u2 linkers because of their cheap prices and comparable coordination ability with the tetrazolate ligands. By employment of such a strategy, two porous MOZs with anionic frameworks, [N(CH3)4]⋅[Zn2(bdc)(5-mtz)3]⋅xsolvent (MOZ-200) and [N(CH3)4]⋅[Zn2(idc)(5-mtz)3]⋅xsolvent (MOZ-201), where 5-mtz = 5-methyltetrazole, were successfully synthesized. Interestingly, in both compounds, the similar nanotube with an 8-membered ring window consisted of 5-mtz ligands and Zn atoms were observed, and the introduction of dicarboxylic acids with different angles resulted in two different zeolite topologies, BCT and ATN. More importantly, MOZ-200 exhibited permanent porosity and high selective CO2 uptake as well as Ln3+ ion exchange.

elements.content: Colorless crystals of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 were obtained by heating the mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, 5-mtz, H2bdc or H2idc, and tetramethylammonium hydroxide [N­(CH3)4OH, 25 wt %] in a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent, respectively (see the Supporting Information for details).
elements.clean_text: Colorless crystals of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 were obtained by heating the mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 5-mtz, H2bdc or H2idc, and tetramethylammonium hydroxide [N(CH3)4OH, 25 wt %] in a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent, respectively (see the Supporting Information for details).

elements.content: Single-crystal structural analysis showed that MOZ-200 crystallizes in the P42/ncm space group. The asymmetric unit includes one Zn2+ ion, one and a half 5-mtz ligand, half of a bdc ligand, half of a [N­(CH3)4]+ cation, and disordered solvent molecules. Each Zn atom is tetrahedrally coordinated by one O atom from the bdc ligand and three N atoms from three 5-mtz ligands (a). All of the 5-mtz ligands act as μ2-bridges to coordinate two Zn atoms by mimicking the coordination mode of 2-methylimidazole. The bdc ligands also serve as μ2-bridges. The length difference of 5-mtz and bdc results in different Zn···Zn distances. For example, the Zn···Zn distances of Zn-5-mtz-Zn are in the range from 6.078 to 6.098 Å. In comparison, a longer Zn···Zn distance (ca. 10.698 Å) of Zn-bdc-Zn is observed.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal structural analysis showed that MOZ-200 crystallizes in the P42/ncm space group. The asymmetric unit includes one Zn2+ ion, one and a half 5-mtz ligand, half of a bdc ligand, half of a [N(CH3)4]+ cation, and disordered solvent molecules. Each Zn atom is tetrahedrally coordinated by one O atom from the bdc ligand and three N atoms from three 5-mtz ligands (a). All of the 5-mtz ligands act as μ2-bridges to coordinate two Zn atoms by mimicking the coordination mode of 2-methylimidazole. The bdc ligands also serve as μ2-bridges. The length difference of 5-mtz and bdc results in different Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances. For example, the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances of Zn-5-mtz-Zn are in the range from 6.078 to 6.098 Å. In comparison, a longer Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance (ca. 10.698 Å) of Zn-bdc-Zn is observed.

elements.content: (a) Coordination mode of the Zn atoms in MOZ-200 and MOZ-201. (b) Zinc tetrazolate octolateral nanotube in MOZ-200 and MOZ-201. 3D frameworks of (c) MOZ-200 and (d) MOZ-201.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination mode of the Zn atoms in MOZ-200 and MOZ-201. (b) Zinc tetrazolate octolateral nanotube in MOZ-200 and MOZ-201. 3D frameworks of (c) MOZ-200 and (d) MOZ-201.

elements.content: The main structural feature of MOZ-200 is its anionic framework. As analyzed above, each Zn atom was connected by three 5-mtz ligands to form a 1D nanotube along the c axis with an 8-membered ring window (b), which can be simplified as a 3-connected (63) topology (b). Note that the N­(CH3)4 + cations as counterions were only filled in this nanotube (Figure S2). Then the bdc ligands link such nanotubes to form the anionic framework (c). Besides the above-mentioned nanotube, the introduction of the bdc ligand gives rise to two other kinds of channels along the c axis. The small one has a 4-membered ring window, which consists of four Zn atoms and two 5-mtz and two bdc ligands, while the big one has an 8-membered ring window and is formed by eight Zn atoms and four bdc and four 5-mtz ligands. The solvent-accessible pore-volume ratio calculated by the PLATON program is ca. 51.0%.
elements.clean_text: The main structural feature of MOZ-200 is its anionic framework. As analyzed above, each Zn atom was connected by three 5-mtz ligands to form a 1D nanotube along the c axis with an 8-membered ring window (b), which can be simplified as a 3-connected (63) topology (b). Note that the N(CH3)4 + cations as counterions were only filled in this nanotube (Figure S2). Then the bdc ligands link such nanotubes to form the anionic framework (c). Besides the above-mentioned nanotube, the introduction of the bdc ligand gives rise to two other kinds of channels along the c axis. The small one has a 4-membered ring window, which consists of four Zn atoms and two 5-mtz and two bdc ligands, while the big one has an 8-membered ring window and is formed by eight Zn atoms and four bdc and four 5-mtz ligands. The solvent-accessible pore-volume ratio calculated by the PLATON program is ca. 51.0%.

elements.content: (a) BCT topology of MOZ-200. (b) Topology of the zinc tetrazolate octolateral channel. (c) lau cage of MOZ-200. (d) ATN topology of MOZ-201. (e) 1D dzc of MOZ-201. (f) atn cage of MOZ-201.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) BCT topology of MOZ-200. (b) Topology of the zinc tetrazolate octolateral channel. (c) lau cage of MOZ-200. (d) ATN topology of MOZ-201. (e) 1D dzc of MOZ-201. (f) atn cage of MOZ-201.

elements.content: Another structural feature in MOZ-200 is that it has a 4-connected BCT network (a). As discussed before, both bdc and 5-mtz act as linkers and each Zn center acts as a 4-connected node. The framework of MOZ-200 can be simplified as a uninodal BCT topology. In addition, MOZ-200 also contains a lau cage formed by 12 Zn atoms and 12 5-mtz and 4 bdc ligands (c).
elements.clean_text: Another structural feature in MOZ-200 is that it has a 4-connected BCT network (a). As discussed before, both bdc and 5-mtz act as linkers and each Zn center acts as a 4-connected node. The framework of MOZ-200 can be simplified as a uninodal BCT topology. In addition, MOZ-200 also contains a lau cage formed by 12 Zn atoms and 12 5-mtz and 4 bdc ligands (c).

elements.content:
Using H2idc to repace H2bdc, another ATN-type MOZ-201 was synhthesized. For MOZ-200 and MOZ-201, different topologies were attributed as the dicarboxylic acids.

MOZ-201 crystallizes in the tetragonal space group P42/ncm. The Zn atoms exhibit almost the same coordination mode in MOZ-201 and MOZ-200. The only difference is that the idc ligand replaces the bdc ligand to serve as a μ2-bridge. Similar Zn···Zn distances of Zn-5-mtz-Zn (ca. 6.122 and 6.142 Å) are observed, while the Zn···Zn distance of Zn-idc-Zn (9.999 Å) is shorter than that of bdc in MOZ-200. Almost the same octolateral nanotube formed by the 5-mtz linkers and Zn atoms is observed in MOZ-201. Such nanotubes are linked by idc ligands to generate a 3D anionic framework (d). In MOZ-201, the solvent-accessible pore-volume ratio is ca. 51.0%.
elements.clean_text:
Using H2idc to repace H2bdc, another ATN-type MOZ-201 was synhthesized. For MOZ-200 and MOZ-201, different topologies were attributed as the dicarboxylic acids.

 MOZ-201 crystallizes in the tetragonal space group P42/ncm. The Zn atoms exhibit almost the same coordination mode in MOZ-201 and MOZ-200. The only difference is that the idc ligand replaces the bdc ligand to serve as a μ2-bridge. Similar Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances of Zn-5-mtz-Zn (ca. 6.122 and 6.142 Å) are observed, while the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of Zn-idc-Zn (9.999 Å) is shorter than that of bdc in MOZ-200. Almost the same octolateral nanotube formed by the 5-mtz linkers and Zn atoms is observed in MOZ-201. Such nanotubes are linked by idc ligands to generate a 3D anionic framework (d). In MOZ-201, the solvent-accessible pore-volume ratio is ca. 51.0%.

elements.content: A prominent feature of MOZ-201 is the presence of a zeolite ATN framework. Similar to MOZ-200, both idc and 5-mtz act as linkers and the Zn center acts as a 4-connected node. The framework can be simplified as a ATN topology (d). The typical atn cage is formed by 24 Zn atoms and 24 5-mtz and 12 idc ligands (f). Additionally, the Zn centers are connected by 5-mtz to form a zigzag chain, and then idc ligands link to adjacent chains to generate a double-zigzag chain (dzc; e).
elements.clean_text: A prominent feature of MOZ-201 is the presence of a zeolite ATN framework. Similar to MOZ-200, both idc and 5-mtz act as linkers and the Zn center acts as a 4-connected node. The framework can be simplified as a ATN topology (d). The typical atn cage is formed by 24 Zn atoms and 24 5-mtz and 12 idc ligands (f). Additionally, the Zn centers are connected by 5-mtz to form a zigzag chain, and then idc ligands link to adjacent chains to generate a double-zigzag chain (dzc; e).

elements.content: It should be noted that different from the previously reported link–link interaction and template effect, different topologies of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 are directed by the angle of two carboxylate groups of ligands. As analyzed previously, MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 crystallize in the same space group, have similar unit cells, and own almost the same zinc tetrazolate nanotubes, but they exhibit different zeolite topologies by the introduction of bdc and idc acids, respectively. For the linear bdc ligand, the angle of two carboxylate groups is 180°, and the Zn-bdc-Zn angle is almost equal to 180°. In comparison, the angle of two carboxylate groups of the idc ligand is 120°, while the Zn-idc-Zn angle is ca. 135°. Such a slight difference results in the formation of different networks.
elements.clean_text: It should be noted that different from the previously reported link-link interaction and template effect, different topologies of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 are directed by the angle of two carboxylate groups of ligands. As analyzed previously, MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 crystallize in the same space group, have similar unit cells, and own almost the same zinc tetrazolate nanotubes, but they exhibit different zeolite topologies by the introduction of bdc and idc acids, respectively. For the linear bdc ligand, the angle of two carboxylate groups is 180°, and the Zn-bdc-Zn angle is almost equal to 180°. In comparison, the angle of two carboxylate groups of the idc ligand is 120°, while the Zn-idc-Zn angle is ca. 135°. Such a slight difference results in the formation of different networks.

elements.content: The chemical stabilities of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 were examined by keeping them in air and soaking the samples in common solvents, such as ethanol, DMF, and CH2Cl2. As proven by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) results, MOZ can be stable in air and such solvents (Figures S5 and S6). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) confirms that MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 showed that approximately 17.5% and 17.4% weight loss, respectively, occurred from 22.5 to 200 °C under a N2 atmosphere (Figure S7). There was no weight loss, and a platform from 200 to 290 °C could be seen before decomposition into two MOZs exchanged by CH2Cl2.
elements.clean_text: The chemical stabilities of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 were examined by keeping them in air and soaking the samples in common solvents, such as ethanol, DMF, and CH2Cl2. As proven by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) results, MOZ can be stable in air and such solvents (Figures S5 and S6). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) confirms that MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 showed that approximately 17.5% and 17.4% weight loss, respectively, occurred from 22.5 to 200 °C under a N2 atmosphere (Figure S7). There was no weight loss, and a platform from 200 to 290 °C could be seen before decomposition into two MOZs exchanged by CH2Cl2.

elements.content: The permanent porosities of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 were checked by gas adsorption on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface-area and pore-size analyzer. To activate the samples, solvent exchange was performed with dry ethanol and CH2Cl2, followed by evacuation at 60 °C for 10 h. The N2 sorption of MOZ-200 at 77 K showed reversible type I adsorption isotherm behavior (a). The Langmuir and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface areas for MOZ-200 were 493 and 317 m2 g–1, respectively. However, the N2 sorption of MOZ-201 at 77 K was negligible (Figure S8).
elements.clean_text: The permanent porosities of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 were checked by gas adsorption on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface-area and pore-size analyzer. To activate the samples, solvent exchange was performed with dry ethanol and CH2Cl2, followed by evacuation at 60 °C for 10 h. The N2 sorption of MOZ-200 at 77 K showed reversible type I adsorption isotherm behavior (a). The Langmuir and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface areas for MOZ-200 were 493 and 317 m2 g-1, respectively. However, the N2 sorption of MOZ-201 at 77 K was negligible (Figure S8).

elements.content: Sorption isotherms of MOZ-200: N2 at 77 K (a), 296 K (b), and 273 K (c); CO2 at 296 K (d) and 273 K (e); CH4 at 296 K (f) and 273 K (g). Solid symbols represent adsorption, and open symbols represent desorption.
elements.clean_text: 3  Sorption isotherms of MOZ-200: N2 at 77 K (a), 296 K (b), and 273 K (c); CO2 at 296 K (d) and 273 K (e); CH4 at 296 K (f) and 273 K (g). Solid symbols represent adsorption, and open symbols represent desorption.

elements.content: Encouraged by the permanent porosity and uncoordinated N sites of MOZ-200, its single-component adsorption isotherms for CO2, N2, and CH4 were researched at 273 and 296 K, respectively (). The maximum adsorption values of CO2 were 44 cm3 g–1 (1.96 mmol g–1) at 273 K and 31 cm3 g–1 (1.40 mmol g–1) at 296 K. On the basis of these data, the isosteric heats of adsorption (Q st) for MOZ-200 were calculated. The adsorption enthalpy of CO2 for MOZ-200 is 20.6 kJ mol–1 at zero coverage (Figures S9 and S10), which is higher than that of MAF-4 without N sites (14.9 kJ mol–1). However, MOZ-200 shows negligible uptake for N2 (2.3 cm3 g–1 at 296 K and 3.1 cm3 g–1 at 273 K) and CH4 (8.1 cm3 g–1 at 296 K and 9.4 cm3 g–1 at 273 K). The maximum uptakes of CO2 and N2 were used to evaluate the CO2/N2 selectivity. The selectivity of CO2/N2 is 19 at 273 K, suggesting that MOZ-200 can be the candidate for the selective separation of CO2 over N2.
elements.clean_text: Encouraged by the permanent porosity and uncoordinated N sites of MOZ-200, its single-component adsorption isotherms for CO2, N2, and CH4 were researched at 273 and 296 K, respectively (). The maximum adsorption values of CO2 were 44 cm3 g-1 (1.96 mmol g-1) at 273 K and 31 cm3 g-1 (1.40 mmol g-1) at 296 K. On the basis of these data, the isosteric heats of adsorption (Q st) for MOZ-200 were calculated. The adsorption enthalpy of CO2 for MOZ-200 is 20.6 kJ mol-1 at zero coverage (Figures S9 and S10), which is higher than that of MAF-4 without N sites (14.9 kJ mol-1). However, MOZ-200 shows negligible uptake for N2 (2.3 cm3 g-1 at 296 K and 3.1 cm3 g-1 at 273 K) and CH4 (8.1 cm3 g-1 at 296 K and 9.4 cm3 g-1 at 273 K). The maximum uptakes of CO2 and N2 were used to evaluate the CO2/N2 selectivity. The selectivity of CO2/N2 is 19 at 273 K, suggesting that MOZ-200 can be the candidate for the selective separation of CO2 over N2.

elements.content: Considering the anionic framework of MOZ-200, we research the potential ion exchange of it. First, the prepared samples were soaked in the DMF solutions of nitrate salts of Ln3+ (Ln3+ = Eu3+ and Tb3+) for 48 h. Then, the samples were filtered off, washed with ethanol several times, and dried in air. The obtained Eu3+@MOZ-200 and Tb3+@MOZ-200 emitted characteristic red and green color of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions excited by a standard UV lamp, which can be observed by the naked eye (a). The success of ion exchange can be proven by analysis of the IR and PXRD patterns (Figures S11 and S12), and the framework of MOZ-200 was kept after the exchange of Ln3+ ions. Furthermore, the luminescence spectra of MOZ-200 and Ln3+@MOZ-200 were also recorded. Upon excitation at 365 nm, MOZ-200 displays a strong emission with a maximum at about 450 nm (b). The Eu3+@MOZ-200 and Tb3+@MOZ-200 samples show intense emission bands at distinctive red and green regions, respectively (c,d). The results indicated that MOZ-200 can be a good candidate for ion exchange.

The obtained Eu3+@MOZ-200 and Tb3+@MOZ-200 emitted characteristic red and green color of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions excited by a standard UV lamp, which can be observed by the naked eye (a). The success of ion exchange can be proven by analysis of the IR and PXRD patterns (Figures S11 and S12), and the framework of MOZ-200 was kept after the exchange of Ln3+ ions. Furthermore, the luminescence spectra of MOZ-200 and Ln3+@MOZ-200 were also recorded. Upon excitation at 365 nm, MOZ-200 displays a strong emission with a maximum at about 450 nm (b). The Eu3+@MOZ-200 and Tb3+@MOZ-200 samples show intense emission bands at distinctive red and green regions, respectively (c,d). The results indicated that MOZ-200 can be a good candidate for ion exchange.

elements.content: (a) Ln3+@MOZ-200 powder observed directly by the naked eye upon 365 nm UV irradiation. Luminescence spectra of MOZ-200 (b), Eu3+@MOZ-200 (c), and Tb3+@MOZ-200 (d) under a 365 nm excitation wavelength.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Ln3+@MOZ-200 powder observed directly by the naked eye upon 365 nm UV irradiation. Luminescence spectra of MOZ-200 (b), Eu3+@MOZ-200 (c), and Tb3+@MOZ-200 (d) under a 365 nm excitation wavelength.

elements.content: In summary, two MOZs with anionic frameworks were successfully synthesized by the mixing of dicarboxylic acid and tetrazole ligands. MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 belong to BCT and ATN topologies, respectively. MOZ-200 exhibits a permanent porosity with gas storage as well as Ln3+ ion exchange.
elements.clean_text: In summary, two MOZs with anionic frameworks were successfully synthesized by the mixing of dicarboxylic acid and tetrazole ligands. MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 belong to BCT and ATN topologies, respectively. MOZ-200 exhibits a permanent porosity with gas storage as well as Ln3+ ion exchange.

cln_elements.content:
The chemical stabilities of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 were examined by keeping them in air and soaking the samples in common solvents, such as ethanol, DMF, and CH2Cl2. As proven by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) results, MOZ can be stable in air and such solvents (Figures S5 and S6). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) confirms that MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 showed that approximately 17.5% and 17.4% weight loss, respectively, occurred from 22.5 to 200 °C under a N2 atmosphere (Figure S7). There was no weight loss, and a platform from 200 to 290 °C could be seen before decomposition into two MOZs exchanged by CH2Cl2.

The permanent porosities of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 were checked by gas adsorption on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface-area and pore-size analyzer. To activate the samples, solvent exchange was performed with dry ethanol and CH2Cl2, followed by evacuation at 60 °C for 10 h. The N2 sorption of MOZ-200 at 77 K showed reversible type I adsorption isotherm behavior (a). The Langmuir and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface areas for MOZ-200 were 493 and 317 m2 g–1, respectively. However, the N2 sorption of MOZ-201 at 77 K was negligible (Figure S8).

Encouraged by the permanent porosity and uncoordinated N sites of MOZ-200, its single-component adsorption isotherms for CO2, N2, and CH4 were researched at 273 and 296 K, respectively (). The maximum adsorption values of CO2 were 44 cm3 g–1 (1.96 mmol g–1) at 273 K and 31 cm3 g–1 (1.40 mmol g–1) at 296 K. On the basis of these data, the isosteric heats of adsorption (Q st) for MOZ-200 were calculated. The adsorption enthalpy of CO2 for MOZ-200 is 20.6 kJ mol–1 at zero coverage (Figures S9 and S10), which is higher than that of MAF-4 without N sites (14.9 kJ mol–1). However, MOZ-200 shows negligible uptake for N2 (2.3 cm3 g–1 at 296 K and 3.1 cm3 g–1 at 273 K) and CH4 (8.1 cm3 g–1 at 296 K and 9.4 cm3 g–1 at 273 K). The maximum uptakes of CO2 and N2 were used to evaluate the CO2/N2 selectivity. The selectivity of CO2/N2 is 19 at 273 K, suggesting that MOZ-200 can be the candidate for the selective separation of CO2 over N2.

As proven by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) results, MOZ can be stable in air and such solvents (Figures S5 and S6). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) confirms that MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 showed that approximately 17.5% and 17.4% weight loss, respectively, occurred from 22.5 to 200 °C under a N2 atmosphere (Figure S7). There was no weight loss, and a platform from 200 to 290 °C could be seen before decomposition into two MOZs exchanged by CH2Cl2.

The permanent porosities of MOZ-200 and MOZ-201 were checked by gas adsorption on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface-area and pore-size analyzer. To activate the samples, solvent exchange was performed with dry ethanol and CH2Cl2, followed by evacuation at 60 °C for 10 h. The N2 sorption of MOZ-200 at 77 K showed reversible type I adsorption isotherm behavior (a). The Langmuir and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface areas for MOZ-200 were 493 and 317 m2 g-1, respectively. However, the N2 sorption of MOZ-201 at 77 K was negligible (Figure S8).

Encouraged by the permanent porosity and uncoordinated N sites of MOZ-200, its single-component adsorption isotherms for CO2, N2, and CH4 were researched at 273 and 296 K, respectively (). The maximum adsorption values of CO2 were 44 cm3 g-1 (1.96 mmol g-1) at 273 K and 31 cm3 g-1 (1.40 mmol g-1) at 296 K. On the basis of these data, the isosteric heats of adsorption (Q st) for MOZ-200 were calculated. The adsorption enthalpy of CO2 for MOZ-200 is 20.6 kJ mol-1 at zero coverage (Figures S9 and S10), which is higher than that of MAF-4 without N sites (14.9 kJ mol-1). However, MOZ-200 shows negligible uptake for N2 (2.3 cm3 g-1 at 296 K and 3.1 cm3 g-1 at 273 K) and CH4 (8.1 cm3 g-1 at 296 K and 9.4 cm3 g-1 at 273 K). The maximum uptakes of CO2 and N2 were used to evaluate the CO2/N2 selectivity. The selectivity of CO2/N2 is 19 at 273 K, suggesting that MOZ-200 can be the candidate for the selective separation of CO2 over N2.

metadata.title:
Synthesis of Anionic Metal–Organic Zeolites
for Selective Gas Adsorption and Ion Exchange
